prevtext:
\title{The Jacquet--Langlands correspondence, Eisenstein congruences,
and integral $L$-values in weight 2}

\author{Kimball Martin\footnote{Department of Mathematics, University of
Oklahoma, Norman, OK 73019}}

\date{\today}

\maketitle

\begin{abstract}
We use the Jacquet--Langlands correspondence to
generalize well-known congruence results of Mazur on Fourier coefficients and
$L$-values of elliptic modular forms for 
prime level in weight 2 both to nonsquare level and to Hilbert modular forms.
\end{abstract}

A celebrated result of Mazur says that, for $N$ a prime and $p$ an odd prime dividing
(the numerator of) $\frac{N-1}{12}$, there exists a cusp form $f \in S_2(N)$ congruent
to the Eisenstein series $E_{2,N}$ of weight 2 and level $N$ mod $p$ \cite[II(5.12)]{mazur1}.  Furthermore,
one has a congruence
for the algebraic part of the  central $L$-value $L(1, f_{K})=L(1, f) L(1, f \otimes
\eta_K)$, where $\eta_K$ is the quadratic character associated to a quadratic field $K/{\mathbb Q}$ \cite{mazur2}.  For instance, if $N=11$, there is one
cusp form $f \in S_2(N)$ and one gets that $L(1, f_K)^{{\rm alg}} \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 5$
if and only if $K$ is not split at 11 and $5 \nmid h_K$.  (If $K$ splits at 11, the root number
is $-1$ so $L(1, f_K) = 0)$.
Later this was reproved by Gross \cite{gross} for $K/{\mathbb Q}$ imaginary quadratic using quaternion algebras and the height pairing, whereas Mazur used modular symbols. 
Ramakrishnan pointed out to me
that one can also deduce this from his average $L$-value formula with 
Michel \cite{michel-ramakrishnan}. (Note Gross's argument also involves an
averaging type procedure, so these two arguments are not entirely different in spirit.)

In this article, we use the Jacquet--Langlands correspondence and an explicit 
$L$-value formula to extend these results of Mazur both to more general levels and to parallel weight 2 Hilbert modular forms over a totally real field $F$ with $K/F$ a quadratic 
CM extension.
For simplicity, we only state our results precisely for $F={\mathbb Q}$ in this introduction:

and $N_1$ has an odd number of prime factors, all of which occur to odd exponents.

be a prime dividing (the numerator of) $\frac 1{12} {\varphi(N_1)N_2} \prod_{p | N_2} (1+p^{-1})$ and ${\mathfrak p}$ a prime of $\overline {\mathbb Q}$ above $p$.  
Then there exists $f \in S_2(N)$ which is an eigenform for $T_n$ with $(n,N) = 1$ and 
 is congruent to the
Eisenstein series $E_{2,N} {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$ away from $N$.

Suppose moreover $N=N_1$ is squarefree and $p | \frac{\varphi(N_1)}{24}$.  
Then we can take $f$ to be a eigennewform such that $f \equiv E_{2,N} {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$
(as $q$-expansions).
If $K/{\mathbb Q}$ is an imaginary quadratic field 
unramified at each prime dividing $N$, and $\chi$ is an ideal class
character of $K$,  we can
normalize $L^{\rm alg}(1, f, \chi)$ so that it is an algebraic integer and

In this case it happens that $f$ and $E_{2,50}$ are congruent mod $5$ everywhere
away from 5, and $f(z) \equiv E_{2,10}(z) - E_{2,10}(5z) {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 5$.

We observe that extending Mazur's $L$-value congruence mod $p$ result
to the case $p=2$ has consequences in the spirit of Goldfeld's conjecture:

\begin{exc} Let $C$ be the unique-up-to-isogeny elliptic curve over ${\mathbb Q}$ of conductor $N=17$.  
Then among negative prime discriminants $-d$, the 
central value $L(1, C_{-d})$ for the quadratic twist $C_{-d}$ is 
nonzero exactly $50\%$ of the time.  
\end{exc}

In fact, we can say precisely when $L(1,C_{-d}) \ne 0$ for $-d < 0$ a prime discriminant. 
We know $C$
is associated to the unique normalized form $f \in S_2(17)$.  We take $p=2$ 
in our theorem and conclude $L^{\rm alg}(1,f_K) \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$ when $17$ is inert in 
$K={\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ and $2 \nmid h_K$.  However, for $d$ prime, Gauss' genus
theory implies $2 \nmid h_K$.  Thus, if $17$ is inert in $K$, 
$L(1,f_K) = L(1,C)L(1,C_{-d}) \ne 0$.
On the other hand, if $17$ is split in ${\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{-d})$, then $L(1,C_{-d})=0$ because the root 
number is $-1$.  In particular, at least 50\% of these prime quadratic twists $C_{-d}$ have 
finitely many rational points.

\medskip
Now we outline the contents and briefly discuss some related works.

In \cref{sec1}, we explain some preliminaries on weight 2 quaternionic modular forms for
totally definite quaternion algebras $B$ over totally real number fields $F$.  These
will be functions on the finite set of ideal classes ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$, for some order ${\mathcal O}$
of $B$.

In \cref{sec2}, we use the Eichler mass formula to show the existence of a
quaternionic cusp form $\phi$ congruent to the constant function modulo suitable primes.
Then we apply the Jacquet--Langlands correspondence to get a Hilbert cusp form 
$f$ corresponding to $\phi$ whose Hecke eigenvalues are congruent to those
of a Hilbert Eisenstein series associated
to the constant function on ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$.  This (\cref{thm1}) is the first main result.

One may also be able to obtain this with appropriate Jacobian calculations along the
lines of Mazur's approach (cf.\ \cite{kamienny}), though there might be additional 
complications in treating $p=2$, $p|N$ or $N$ not squarefree.  On the other hand, our approach 
is completely different and a very simple consequence of the Jacquet--Langlands 
correspondence and the 
arithmetic of definite quaternion algebras, which 
extends to the Hilbert modular case with a bit of care (though we assume 
$h_F^+ = h_F$ for simplicity; cf.\ \cref{rem:thm1}). We note recent work
of Berger, Klosin and Kramer \cite{bkk} gives an algebraic approach to  
congruences of Hecke eigenvalues in more general settings, which yields
a refinement of Mazur's Fourier coefficient congruence on $S_2(N)$ when $N$ is prime.  
In the case of Hilbert modular forms, results are already known about
 finding primes of congruence between two \emph{cusp} forms, 
e.g., the work of Ghate \cite{ghate}, which generalizes a result of
Hida \cite{hida} on elliptic modular  forms.

Finally, in \cref{sec3}, we use an explicit version of Waldspurger's 
formula relating central $L$-values to periods on quaternion algebras.  By appropriate
normalization, the period (and the algebraic part of the $L$-value) will be integral
and one uses the fact that for a form $f$ as above, the relevant period must be congruent
to the period for the constant function $1$.  This gives our $L$-value congruence (\cref{thm2}).
This approach
is analogous to Gross's proof of Mazur's result, which followed from first proving an
$L$-value formula in terms of the height pairing (which in this case is essentially a period 
on a quaternion algebra).  In our case, we apply the explicit $L$-value formula obtained
in earlier collaboration with Whitehouse \cite{mw}.  That $L$-value formula applies to
arbitrary quadratic extensions $K/F$ ($F$ totally real or not), but we need to restrict to
$K/F$ CM here in order for the relevant period to lie on the definite quaternion algebra 
$B$.

When $F={\mathbb Q}$ and the ideal class character $\chi$ of $K$ is trivial,
many results along the lines of ``congruence of Fourier coefficients implies congruence
of $L$-values'' are known.
The most recent and relevant to our situation is the paper
of Heumann and Vatsal \cite{hv}, which extends earlier work of Stevens \cite{stevens}.
Like \cite{mazur2} and other works, they use the method of
modular symbols.   In particular, \cite{hv} says that if an elliptic modular
form and an Eisenstein series in $S_k(N)$ ($k \ge 2$) are congruent mod ${\mathfrak p}$, 
one has a certain congruence of twisted $L$-values $L(m, f \otimes \eta)$ 
(all special values, not just central) where $\eta$ is a Dirichlet character.  
In \cite{hv}, it is also mentioned that Yuichi Hirano announced a similar result.
Note this approach involves the choice of a canonical period,
which is only well-defined up to $p$-adic units, as was also the case in \cite{mazur2}. 
On the other hand, we normalize
the algebraic parts of our $L$-values in a unique way, 
so our congruence does not depend upon a $p$-adic unit. (Our normalization depends
on the quaternionic form $\phi$ in a computationally simple way).

There are also some existence results of a different nature about even weight elliptic or 
Hilbert cusp forms with $L(1, f, \chi)^{\rm alg} \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$ using average
value formulas, e.g., the aforementioned work of Michel and Ramakrishnan
\cite{michel-ramakrishnan} and joint work of File and Pitale with the present author 
\cite{fmp}.  However, these are of the form that
for a given ${\mathfrak p}$ there just exists some such $f$ for suitably large level, where the
bound on the level \emph{depends on $K$}. 
On the other hand,
I am not aware of any results along the lines of $L(1, f, \chi)^{\rm alg}$ vanishes mod ${\mathfrak p}$
for $\chi$ nontrivial when the sign of the functional equation is $+1$.

\section{Quaternionic modular forms} \label{sec1}







Throughout, we fix the following notation.  Let $F$ be a totally real number field of degree
$d$, and ${\mathfrak o}_F$ its ring of integers.
Let ${\mathfrak N}={\mathfrak N}_1 {\mathfrak N}_2$ be a nonzero integral ideal in ${\mathfrak o}_F$
such that ${\mathfrak N}_1={\mathfrak p}_1^{e_1} \cdots {\mathfrak p}_{r}^{e_{r}}$ and  
${\mathfrak N}_2 = {\mathfrak q}_1^{f_1} \cdots {\mathfrak q}_s^{f_s}$ where the ${\mathfrak p}_i$'s and ${\mathfrak q}_j$'s are 
distinct prime ideals of ${\mathfrak o}_F$, $e_i, f_j \in {\mathbb N}$, each $e_i$ is odd, and $r \equiv d {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$.
Note that ${\mathfrak N}$ can be any nonzero ideal when $d$ is even, and ${\mathfrak N}$ can be any ideal
which is not a square when $d$ is odd.  The letter $\ell$ will denote a finite prime of $F$.

Denote by $B$ the unique (up to isomorphism) totally definite quaternion algebra over $F$ 
ramified at each ${\mathfrak p}_i$ and no other finite prime.  
Let ${\mathcal O}$ be an order of level ${\mathfrak N}$ in $B$ such that ${\mathcal O}_{{\mathfrak q}_i}$
is conjugate to $R_0({\mathfrak q}_i^{f_i})$, the subring of $M_2({\mathfrak o}_{F,{\mathfrak q}_i})$ with lower
left entry $0$ mod ${\mathfrak q}_i^{f_i}$.  Note this is an Eichler order if ${\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree---otherwise
it is the intersection of an Eichler order of level $\prod {\mathfrak p}_i \cdot {\mathfrak N}_2$ with
 an order, which is unique up to isomorphism, of level ${\mathfrak N}_1$.

Here ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ can naturally be viewed as the (finite) set of invertible (i.e., locally principal)
 right ideal classes of ${\mathcal O}$.  We denote the class number $\# {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ by $h({\mathcal O})$.
Let  ${\mathcal I}_1, \cdots, {\mathcal I}_h$ be a set of representatives for the right ideal
classes of ${\mathcal O}$, and let $x_1, \ldots, x_h$ be a corresponding set of representatives
for the double coset classes $B^\times {\backslash} \hat{B^\times} / \hat {\mathcal O}^\times$.

We consider the space of (weight 2, or weight 0, depending on convention)

prevtext:
In this case it happens that $f$ and $E_{2,50}$ are congruent mod $5$ everywhere
away from 5, and $f(z) \equiv E_{2,10}(z) - E_{2,10}(5z) {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 5$.

We observe that extending Mazur's $L$-value congruence mod $p$ result
to the case $p=2$ has consequences in the spirit of Goldfeld's conjecture:

\begin{exc} Let $C$ be the unique-up-to-isogeny elliptic curve over ${\mathbb Q}$ of conductor $N=17$.  
Then among negative prime discriminants $-d$, the 
central value $L(1, C_{-d})$ for the quadratic twist $C_{-d}$ is 
nonzero exactly $50\%$ of the time.  
\end{exc}

In fact, we can say precisely when $L(1,C_{-d}) \ne 0$ for $-d < 0$ a prime discriminant. 
We know $C$
is associated to the unique normalized form $f \in S_2(17)$.  We take $p=2$ 
in our theorem and conclude $L^{\rm alg}(1,f_K) \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$ when $17$ is inert in 
$K={\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ and $2 \nmid h_K$.  However, for $d$ prime, Gauss' genus
theory implies $2 \nmid h_K$.  Thus, if $17$ is inert in $K$, 
$L(1,f_K) = L(1,C)L(1,C_{-d}) \ne 0$.
On the other hand, if $17$ is split in ${\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{-d})$, then $L(1,C_{-d})=0$ because the root 
number is $-1$.  In particular, at least 50\% of these prime quadratic twists $C_{-d}$ have 
finitely many rational points.

\medskip
Now we outline the contents and briefly discuss some related works.

In \cref{sec1}, we explain some preliminaries on weight 2 quaternionic modular forms for
totally definite quaternion algebras $B$ over totally real number fields $F$.  These
will be functions on the finite set of ideal classes ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$, for some order ${\mathcal O}$
of $B$.

In \cref{sec2}, we use the Eichler mass formula to show the existence of a
quaternionic cusp form $\phi$ congruent to the constant function modulo suitable primes.
Then we apply the Jacquet--Langlands correspondence to get a Hilbert cusp form 
$f$ corresponding to $\phi$ whose Hecke eigenvalues are congruent to those
of a Hilbert Eisenstein series associated
to the constant function on ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$.  This (\cref{thm1}) is the first main result.

One may also be able to obtain this with appropriate Jacobian calculations along the
lines of Mazur's approach (cf.\ \cite{kamienny}), though there might be additional 
complications in treating $p=2$, $p|N$ or $N$ not squarefree.  On the other hand, our approach 
is completely different and a very simple consequence of the Jacquet--Langlands 
correspondence and the 
arithmetic of definite quaternion algebras, which 
extends to the Hilbert modular case with a bit of care (though we assume 
$h_F^+ = h_F$ for simplicity; cf.\ \cref{rem:thm1}). We note recent work
of Berger, Klosin and Kramer \cite{bkk} gives an algebraic approach to  
congruences of Hecke eigenvalues in more general settings, which yields
a refinement of Mazur's Fourier coefficient congruence on $S_2(N)$ when $N$ is prime.  
In the case of Hilbert modular forms, results are already known about
 finding primes of congruence between two \emph{cusp} forms, 
e.g., the work of Ghate \cite{ghate}, which generalizes a result of
Hida \cite{hida} on elliptic modular  forms.

Finally, in \cref{sec3}, we use an explicit version of Waldspurger's 
formula relating central $L$-values to periods on quaternion algebras.  By appropriate
normalization, the period (and the algebraic part of the $L$-value) will be integral
and one uses the fact that for a form $f$ as above, the relevant period must be congruent
to the period for the constant function $1$.  This gives our $L$-value congruence (\cref{thm2}).
This approach
is analogous to Gross's proof of Mazur's result, which followed from first proving an
$L$-value formula in terms of the height pairing (which in this case is essentially a period 
on a quaternion algebra).  In our case, we apply the explicit $L$-value formula obtained
in earlier collaboration with Whitehouse \cite{mw}.  That $L$-value formula applies to
arbitrary quadratic extensions $K/F$ ($F$ totally real or not), but we need to restrict to
$K/F$ CM here in order for the relevant period to lie on the definite quaternion algebra 
$B$.

When $F={\mathbb Q}$ and the ideal class character $\chi$ of $K$ is trivial,
many results along the lines of ``congruence of Fourier coefficients implies congruence
of $L$-values'' are known.
The most recent and relevant to our situation is the paper
of Heumann and Vatsal \cite{hv}, which extends earlier work of Stevens \cite{stevens}.
Like \cite{mazur2} and other works, they use the method of
modular symbols.   In particular, \cite{hv} says that if an elliptic modular
form and an Eisenstein series in $S_k(N)$ ($k \ge 2$) are congruent mod ${\mathfrak p}$, 
one has a certain congruence of twisted $L$-values $L(m, f \otimes \eta)$ 
(all special values, not just central) where $\eta$ is a Dirichlet character.  
In \cite{hv}, it is also mentioned that Yuichi Hirano announced a similar result.
Note this approach involves the choice of a canonical period,
which is only well-defined up to $p$-adic units, as was also the case in \cite{mazur2}. 
On the other hand, we normalize
the algebraic parts of our $L$-values in a unique way, 
so our congruence does not depend upon a $p$-adic unit. (Our normalization depends
on the quaternionic form $\phi$ in a computationally simple way).

There are also some existence results of a different nature about even weight elliptic or 
Hilbert cusp forms with $L(1, f, \chi)^{\rm alg} \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$ using average
value formulas, e.g., the aforementioned work of Michel and Ramakrishnan
\cite{michel-ramakrishnan} and joint work of File and Pitale with the present author 
\cite{fmp}.  However, these are of the form that
for a given ${\mathfrak p}$ there just exists some such $f$ for suitably large level, where the
bound on the level \emph{depends on $K$}. 
On the other hand,
I am not aware of any results along the lines of $L(1, f, \chi)^{\rm alg}$ vanishes mod ${\mathfrak p}$
for $\chi$ nontrivial when the sign of the functional equation is $+1$.

\section{Quaternionic modular forms} \label{sec1}







Throughout, we fix the following notation.  Let $F$ be a totally real number field of degree
$d$, and ${\mathfrak o}_F$ its ring of integers.
Let ${\mathfrak N}={\mathfrak N}_1 {\mathfrak N}_2$ be a nonzero integral ideal in ${\mathfrak o}_F$
such that ${\mathfrak N}_1={\mathfrak p}_1^{e_1} \cdots {\mathfrak p}_{r}^{e_{r}}$ and  
${\mathfrak N}_2 = {\mathfrak q}_1^{f_1} \cdots {\mathfrak q}_s^{f_s}$ where the ${\mathfrak p}_i$'s and ${\mathfrak q}_j$'s are 
distinct prime ideals of ${\mathfrak o}_F$, $e_i, f_j \in {\mathbb N}$, each $e_i$ is odd, and $r \equiv d {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$.
Note that ${\mathfrak N}$ can be any nonzero ideal when $d$ is even, and ${\mathfrak N}$ can be any ideal
which is not a square when $d$ is odd.  The letter $\ell$ will denote a finite prime of $F$.

Denote by $B$ the unique (up to isomorphism) totally definite quaternion algebra over $F$ 
ramified at each ${\mathfrak p}_i$ and no other finite prime.  
Let ${\mathcal O}$ be an order of level ${\mathfrak N}$ in $B$ such that ${\mathcal O}_{{\mathfrak q}_i}$
is conjugate to $R_0({\mathfrak q}_i^{f_i})$, the subring of $M_2({\mathfrak o}_{F,{\mathfrak q}_i})$ with lower
left entry $0$ mod ${\mathfrak q}_i^{f_i}$.  Note this is an Eichler order if ${\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree---otherwise
it is the intersection of an Eichler order of level $\prod {\mathfrak p}_i \cdot {\mathfrak N}_2$ with
 an order, which is unique up to isomorphism, of level ${\mathfrak N}_1$.

We want to work with a certain space of automorphic forms on $B^\times$.  Adelically,
we will be looking at functions on

Note that $M({\mathcal O}, 1) = M({\mathcal O})$ if $F$ has class number 1, because in this case
$\hat F^\times = F^\times \hat {\mathfrak o}_F^\times \subset B^\times \hat {\mathcal O}^\times$.
In general ${\mathcal M}$ is a complex vector space of dimension $h({\mathcal O}) - (m-1)$ where $m$
is size the image of the map ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_F) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ induced from inclusion
${\mathbb A}_F^\times \to B^\times({\mathbb A}_F)$, so we always have
$h({\mathcal O}) - h_F + 1 \le \dim {\mathcal M} \le h({\mathcal O})$.  When $h_F$ is odd, 
composing with the reduced norm shows the map 
${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_F) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ is injective so $\dim {\mathcal M} = h({\mathcal O}) - h_F +1$.

Now we want to define the Eisenstein and cuspidal subspaces of ${\mathcal M}$.
The Eisenstein space will be generated by the one-dimensional representations of
$\hat B^\times$, which all factor through the reduced norm map $N: \hat B^\times \to
\hat F^+$.  The reduced norm induces a surjective map $N: {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O}) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}^+({\mathfrak o}_F)$
to the narrow class group of $F$.
Define the Eisenstein subspace ${\mathcal E}$ of ${\mathcal M}$ to be the subspace of all 
$\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ which factor through $N$, and the cuspidal space ${\mathcal S}$ to be the
orthogonal complement of ${\mathcal E}$ in ${\mathcal M}$.  
We can describe ${\mathcal S}$ in terms of our normalized pairing \eqref{eq:normpair} by

nexttext:
One has in the usual way Hecke operators $T_\ell$ for each prime $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$, 
which commute with each other and are self-adjoint with respect to the inner product.  
Hence ${\mathcal M}$,
and also ${\mathcal S}$, has a basis consisting of eigenforms for each such $T_\ell$.  
Via the Jacquet--Langlands correspondence, each eigenform $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ transfers to an
eigenform $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$, the space of parallel weight 2 Hilbert modular forms
of level ${\mathfrak N}$, with the same Hecke eigenvalues away from ${\mathfrak N}$.

Suppose moreover ${\mathfrak N}_1 = {\mathfrak p}_1 \cdots {\mathfrak p}_r$ is squarefree.  Then for $\ell | {\mathfrak N}_1$,
one can define a Hecke operator by $(T_\ell \phi)(x) = \phi(x \varpi_{B_\ell})$ where
$\varpi_{B_\ell}$ is a uniformizer for  $B_\ell$.  This corresponds to the double coset
${\mathcal O}_\ell \varpi_{B_\ell} {\mathcal O}_\ell = \varpi_{B_\ell} {\mathcal O}_\ell$.  
Now one has bases for ${\mathcal M}$ and ${\mathcal S}$ which are eigenforms
 for all $T_\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}_2$, and the Jacquet--Langlands lift of such an eigenform $\phi$
 will be a modular form $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$ which, at each $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}_2$, is new and is
 an eigenform for $T_\ell$ with the same eigenvalue as $\phi$.  





\section{Congruence with Eisenstein series} \label{sec2}





We keep the notation of the previous section.  

For $f \in M_2({\mathfrak N})$ (resp.\ $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$) which is an 
eigenfunction of the Hecke operator $T_\ell$, let $\lambda_\ell(f)$ 
(resp.\ $\lambda_\ell(\phi)$) denote the corresponding eigenvalue.

Let $E$ be the normalized Eisenstein series on $M_2({\mathfrak N})$
with Hecke eigenvalues $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = N(\ell) + 1$ when
$\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$ and $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = 1$ when $\ell | {\mathfrak N}$.  When $F={\mathbb Q}$, this is 
the $E_{2,N}$ explicitly constructed in the introduction.  Recall $\phi_0 = 1 \in {\mathcal E}$.
Observe $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = \lambda_{\ell}(\phi_0)$  
when $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$, and in fact for all $\ell$ when
${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree. 

The field of rationality of an eigenform $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ is the field ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$ generated by 
its Hecke eigenvalues.  We may normalize $\phi$ so that all values of $\phi$ are integers
in ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$, in which case we say $\phi$ is integral.
Let ${\mathbb Q}({\mathfrak N})$ be the compositum of the fields of rationality ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$ of all
eigenforms in $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$.  Note this is a subfield of the compositum of all
${\mathbb Q}(f)$ where $f$ ranges over eigenforms in $S_2({\mathfrak N})$.  

\begin{thm} \label{thm1} Assume $h_F^+ = h_F$.
If $h_F^+ > 1$, we also assume $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F^+$.
Let ${\mathrm{num}}$ be the numerator of $m({\mathcal O})$.  
Suppose $p | {\mathrm{num}}$
and ${\mathfrak p}$ is a prime above $p$ in ${\mathbb Q}({\mathfrak N})$.   Then there exists an eigenform $f \in S_{2}({\mathfrak N})$ such that
$\lambda_\ell(f) \equiv \lambda_{\ell}(E) {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$
 for all $\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$.  
 If ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree, we may extend this congruence to all $\ell$.
 \end{thm}

\begin{proof} The condition $h_F^+ = h_F$ means ${\mathcal E} = \langle \phi_0 \rangle$.
Recall $\dim {\mathcal M} \ge h({\mathcal O}) - (h_F -1)$.  Thus ${\mathcal M} \ne {\mathcal E}$ 
if $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F = h_F^+$.  In the case $h_F^+ = 1$, this is automatically satisfied
by the assumption $p | {\mathrm{num}}$, because $h({\mathcal O}) = 1$ implies ${\mathrm{num}} = 1$.  Thus
our hypotheses guarantee $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F$ and ${\mathcal M} \ne {\mathcal E}$.

Now we observe there exists an integral $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ such that
$\phi \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$ .  To see this, take
$\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ such that $\phi({\mathcal I}_i) = 1 + pa_i$ for each ${\mathcal I}_i \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$
where $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$.  Note $\phi \in
{\mathcal M}$ means that up to $h_F$ of the $a_i$'s must be the same.
We have $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ if $[\phi, \phi_0] = 0$, i.e., if
$p \sum w_i^{-1} a_i = -m({\mathcal O})$.  This
is solvable for $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$ since $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F$ and $p | {\mathrm{num}}$.

We further claim that we can take $\phi$ to be an eigenfunction for  $T_\ell$ for all $\ell$
with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$, and in fact for all $\ell$ if ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree.  
At the least, there is a collection of integral eigenfunctions $\phi_j \in {\mathcal S}$ for such $T_\ell$
satisfying $\phi_0 \equiv \phi \equiv \sum_{j=1}^r \phi_j {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$.  We may assume that
the $\phi_j$'s are linearly independent mod ${\mathfrak p}$.      Then

The Eisenstein space will be generated by the one-dimensional representations of
$\hat B^\times$, which all factor through the reduced norm map $N: \hat B^\times \to
\hat F^+$.  The reduced norm induces a surjective map $N: {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O}) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}^+({\mathfrak o}_F)$
to the narrow class group of $F$.
Define the Eisenstein subspace ${\mathcal E}$ of ${\mathcal M}$ to be the subspace of all 
$\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ which factor through $N$, and the cuspidal space ${\mathcal S}$ to be the
orthogonal complement of ${\mathcal E}$ in ${\mathcal M}$.  
We can describe ${\mathcal S}$ in terms of our normalized pairing \eqref{eq:normpair} by

\text{ for all characters } \psi: {\mathrm{Cl}}^+({\mathfrak o}_F)/{\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_F) \to {\mathbb C} \}. \]

nexttext:
By linear independence mod ${\mathfrak p}$, we get $\lambda_\ell(\phi_j) \equiv \lambda_\ell(\phi_0)$ mod
${\mathfrak p}$ for each $j$.
So we may take $\phi = \phi_1$, and $f$ to be the Jacquet--Langlands lift of $\phi$.

Since $f$ has the same Hecke eigenvalues as $\phi$ for $T_\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$
(resp.\ any $\ell$) for arbitrary ${\mathfrak N}$ (resp.\ ${\mathfrak N}= {\mathfrak N}_1$ squarefree), this yields
the theorem.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem} \label{rem:thm1}
(a) Recall we always have $h({\mathcal O}) \ge h_F^+$.  Since $h({\mathcal O}) > m({\mathcal O})$,
the mass formula implies $h({\mathcal O}) = h_F^+$ for at most finitely many choices of ${\mathfrak N}$;
i.e., for fixed $F$, the condition $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F^+$ holds for almost all ${\mathfrak N}$.

(b) The reason we assume $h_F^+ = h_F$ is to guarantee
the existence of $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ such that $\phi \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$.  If
$h_F^+ \ne h_F$, one gets an additional linear constraint
$[\phi, \psi \circ N]=0$ on the $a_i$'s in the proof for each nontrivial character $\psi$ of 
${\mathrm{Cl}}^+({\mathfrak o}_F)/{\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_F)$.
Then, at least a priori, one needs to place some conditions on the $w_i$'s, $m({\mathcal O})$
and $p$ to guarantee the existence of $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$ solving this system of 
${\mathbb Q}$-linear equations.

(c) When $h_F^+ = h_F > 1$, there are other Eisenstein series in $M({\mathcal O})$, and one 
might ask for congruences of these Eisenstein series as well.  However, such Eisenstein 
series which are also eigenforms can be obtained by 
twisting $\phi_0$ by narrow ideal class characters of $F$, 
and analogous congruences are just obtained by twisting both $E$ and $f$.
\end{rem}

We observe that there are often multiple choices for $B$ for a given ${\mathfrak N}$.
For instance, if $F={\mathbb Q}$ and $N=11 \cdot 13$, we get ${\mathrm{num}} = 5 \cdot 7$ if we take 
$N_1 = 11$, $N_2 = 13$ and ${\mathrm{num}} = 12$ if we take $N_1 = 13$, $N_2 = 11$.
Thus one gets congruences of cusp forms in level $11 \cdot 13$ 
with Eisenstein series modulo the primes $p = 2, 3, 5, 7$.

Some examples with $F={\mathbb Q}$ were given in the introduction.
Here is a simple example with $F\neq {\mathbb Q}$.

\begin{ex} Let $F = {\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{5})$, which has narrow class number $1$.  
Suppose ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_2$ is one of the two prime ideals
with $N({\mathfrak N}) = 31$.  Then $\zeta_F(-1) = \frac 1{30}$ and $m({\mathcal O}) = \frac{32}{60} = \frac 8{15}$, 
so we take $p=2$.  Here
$S_2({\mathfrak N})$ is one dimensional and has rationality field ${\mathbb Q}$.  
Then for nonzero $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$ our theorem says that $\lambda_\ell(f) \equiv N(\ell) + 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$ 
for $\ell \ne {\mathfrak N}$.  It is also true that $\lambda_{\mathfrak N} (f) \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$.
Indeed, the first few nonzero Hecke 
eigenvalues  $\lambda_\ell$ satisfy the values listed in the following table:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|ccccccccccccc}
$N(\ell)$ & $4$ & $5$ & $9$ & $11$ & $11$ & $19$ & $19$ & $29$ & $29$ & $31$ & $31$ & $41$ & $41$ \\
\hline
$\lambda_\ell$ & $-3$ & $-2$ & $2$ & $4$ & $-4$ & $-4$ & $4$ & $-2$ & $-2$ & $-1$ & $8$ & $-6$ & $-6$
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{ex}









\section{Integral parts of $L$-values} \label{sec3}





We keep our previous notation, but now assume ${\mathcal O}$ is a maximal order of $B$, i.e.,
${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ and is squarefree.  For consistency and clarity, 
we will denote complete $L$-functions by $L^*(s, -)$ and incomplete $L$-functions just by $L(s, -)$.  However, we follow the usual convention that automorphic 
$L$-functions are normalized
so that $s=1/2$ is the central value, whereas $L$-functions for $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$
are normalized classically with $s=1$ the central value.

Let $K/F$ be a CM quadratic extension such that $K$ is unramified
at each ${\mathfrak p} | {\mathfrak N}$.  This means $K$ embeds in $B$ and, since we
are now assuming ${\mathcal O}$ is maximal, we may fix an embedding of $K$ into $B$
such that ${\mathfrak o}_K \subset {\mathcal O}$. Hence, for 
$t \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K) = K^\times {\backslash} \hat K^\times / \hat {\mathfrak o}_K^\times$, we can associate the
quaternionic ideal class $x(t) \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ via $x(t) = B^\times t \hat {\mathcal O}^\times$.
Fix a character $\chi$ of ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K)$.  Put the product of local Tamagawa measures
on ${\mathbb A}_F^\times$ and ${\mathbb A}_K^\times$, and the counting measure on $K^\times$.
For $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$, define the period

${\mathcal O}_\ell \varpi_{B_\ell} {\mathcal O}_\ell = \varpi_{B_\ell} {\mathcal O}_\ell$.  
Now one has bases for ${\mathcal M}$ and ${\mathcal S}$ which are eigenforms
 for all $T_\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}_2$, and the Jacquet--Langlands lift of such an eigenform $\phi$
 will be a modular form $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$ which, at each $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}_2$, is new and is
 an eigenform for $T_\ell$ with the same eigenvalue as $\phi$.  





\section{Congruence with Eisenstein series} \label{sec2}





We keep the notation of the previous section.  

For $f \in M_2({\mathfrak N})$ (resp.\ $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$) which is an 
eigenfunction of the Hecke operator $T_\ell$, let $\lambda_\ell(f)$ 
(resp.\ $\lambda_\ell(\phi)$) denote the corresponding eigenvalue.

Let $E$ be the normalized Eisenstein series on $M_2({\mathfrak N})$
with Hecke eigenvalues $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = N(\ell) + 1$ when
$\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$ and $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = 1$ when $\ell | {\mathfrak N}$.  When $F={\mathbb Q}$, this is 
the $E_{2,N}$ explicitly constructed in the introduction.  Recall $\phi_0 = 1 \in {\mathcal E}$.
Observe $\lambda_{\ell}(E) = \lambda_{\ell}(\phi_0)$  
when $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$, and in fact for all $\ell$ when
${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree. 

The field of rationality of an eigenform $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ is the field ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$ generated by 
its Hecke eigenvalues.  We may normalize $\phi$ so that all values of $\phi$ are integers
in ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$, in which case we say $\phi$ is integral.
Let ${\mathbb Q}({\mathfrak N})$ be the compositum of the fields of rationality ${\mathbb Q}(\phi)$ of all
eigenforms in $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$.  Note this is a subfield of the compositum of all
${\mathbb Q}(f)$ where $f$ ranges over eigenforms in $S_2({\mathfrak N})$.  

\begin{thm} \label{thm1} Assume $h_F^+ = h_F$.
If $h_F^+ > 1$, we also assume $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F^+$.
Let ${\mathrm{num}}$ be the numerator of $m({\mathcal O})$.  
Suppose $p | {\mathrm{num}}$
and ${\mathfrak p}$ is a prime above $p$ in ${\mathbb Q}({\mathfrak N})$.   Then there exists an eigenform $f \in S_{2}({\mathfrak N})$ such that
$\lambda_\ell(f) \equiv \lambda_{\ell}(E) {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$
 for all $\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$.  
 If ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree, we may extend this congruence to all $\ell$.
 \end{thm}

\begin{proof} The condition $h_F^+ = h_F$ means ${\mathcal E} = \langle \phi_0 \rangle$.
Recall $\dim {\mathcal M} \ge h({\mathcal O}) - (h_F -1)$.  Thus ${\mathcal M} \ne {\mathcal E}$ 
if $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F = h_F^+$.  In the case $h_F^+ = 1$, this is automatically satisfied
by the assumption $p | {\mathrm{num}}$, because $h({\mathcal O}) = 1$ implies ${\mathrm{num}} = 1$.  Thus
our hypotheses guarantee $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F$ and ${\mathcal M} \ne {\mathcal E}$.

Now we observe there exists an integral $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ such that
$\phi \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$ .  To see this, take
$\phi \in {\mathcal M}$ such that $\phi({\mathcal I}_i) = 1 + pa_i$ for each ${\mathcal I}_i \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$
where $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$.  Note $\phi \in
{\mathcal M}$ means that up to $h_F$ of the $a_i$'s must be the same.
We have $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ if $[\phi, \phi_0] = 0$, i.e., if
$p \sum w_i^{-1} a_i = -m({\mathcal O})$.  This
is solvable for $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$ since $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F$ and $p | {\mathrm{num}}$.

We further claim that we can take $\phi$ to be an eigenfunction for  $T_\ell$ for all $\ell$
with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$, and in fact for all $\ell$ if ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ is squarefree.  
At the least, there is a collection of integral eigenfunctions $\phi_j \in {\mathcal S}$ for such $T_\ell$
satisfying $\phi_0 \equiv \phi \equiv \sum_{j=1}^r \phi_j {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$.  We may assume that
the $\phi_j$'s are linearly independent mod ${\mathfrak p}$.      Then

\phi_{0}\equiv\sum_{j=1}^{r}\lambda_{\ell}(\phi_{0})\phi_{j}{\,\,\mathrm{mod}%

prevtext:
By linear independence mod ${\mathfrak p}$, we get $\lambda_\ell(\phi_j) \equiv \lambda_\ell(\phi_0)$ mod
${\mathfrak p}$ for each $j$.
So we may take $\phi = \phi_1$, and $f$ to be the Jacquet--Langlands lift of $\phi$.

Since $f$ has the same Hecke eigenvalues as $\phi$ for $T_\ell$ with $\ell \nmid {\mathfrak N}$
(resp.\ any $\ell$) for arbitrary ${\mathfrak N}$ (resp.\ ${\mathfrak N}= {\mathfrak N}_1$ squarefree), this yields
the theorem.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem} \label{rem:thm1}
(a) Recall we always have $h({\mathcal O}) \ge h_F^+$.  Since $h({\mathcal O}) > m({\mathcal O})$,
the mass formula implies $h({\mathcal O}) = h_F^+$ for at most finitely many choices of ${\mathfrak N}$;
i.e., for fixed $F$, the condition $h({\mathcal O}) > h_F^+$ holds for almost all ${\mathfrak N}$.

(b) The reason we assume $h_F^+ = h_F$ is to guarantee
the existence of $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ such that $\phi \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$.  If
$h_F^+ \ne h_F$, one gets an additional linear constraint
$[\phi, \psi \circ N]=0$ on the $a_i$'s in the proof for each nontrivial character $\psi$ of 
${\mathrm{Cl}}^+({\mathfrak o}_F)/{\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_F)$.
Then, at least a priori, one needs to place some conditions on the $w_i$'s, $m({\mathcal O})$
and $p$ to guarantee the existence of $a_i \in {\mathbb Z}$ solving this system of 
${\mathbb Q}$-linear equations.

(c) When $h_F^+ = h_F > 1$, there are other Eisenstein series in $M({\mathcal O})$, and one 
might ask for congruences of these Eisenstein series as well.  However, such Eisenstein 
series which are also eigenforms can be obtained by 
twisting $\phi_0$ by narrow ideal class characters of $F$, 
and analogous congruences are just obtained by twisting both $E$ and $f$.
\end{rem}

We observe that there are often multiple choices for $B$ for a given ${\mathfrak N}$.
For instance, if $F={\mathbb Q}$ and $N=11 \cdot 13$, we get ${\mathrm{num}} = 5 \cdot 7$ if we take 
$N_1 = 11$, $N_2 = 13$ and ${\mathrm{num}} = 12$ if we take $N_1 = 13$, $N_2 = 11$.
Thus one gets congruences of cusp forms in level $11 \cdot 13$ 
with Eisenstein series modulo the primes $p = 2, 3, 5, 7$.

Some examples with $F={\mathbb Q}$ were given in the introduction.
Here is a simple example with $F\neq {\mathbb Q}$.

\begin{ex} Let $F = {\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{5})$, which has narrow class number $1$.  
Suppose ${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_2$ is one of the two prime ideals
with $N({\mathfrak N}) = 31$.  Then $\zeta_F(-1) = \frac 1{30}$ and $m({\mathcal O}) = \frac{32}{60} = \frac 8{15}$, 
so we take $p=2$.  Here
$S_2({\mathfrak N})$ is one dimensional and has rationality field ${\mathbb Q}$.  
Then for nonzero $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$ our theorem says that $\lambda_\ell(f) \equiv N(\ell) + 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$ 
for $\ell \ne {\mathfrak N}$.  It is also true that $\lambda_{\mathfrak N} (f) \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 2$.
Indeed, the first few nonzero Hecke 
eigenvalues  $\lambda_\ell$ satisfy the values listed in the following table:

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{c|ccccccccccccc}
$N(\ell)$ & $4$ & $5$ & $9$ & $11$ & $11$ & $19$ & $19$ & $29$ & $29$ & $31$ & $31$ & $41$ & $41$ \\
\hline
$\lambda_\ell$ & $-3$ & $-2$ & $2$ & $4$ & $-4$ & $-4$ & $4$ & $-2$ & $-2$ & $-1$ & $8$ & $-6$ & $-6$
\end{tabular}
\end{center}
\end{ex}









\section{Integral parts of $L$-values} \label{sec3}





We keep our previous notation, but now assume ${\mathcal O}$ is a maximal order of $B$, i.e.,
${\mathfrak N} = {\mathfrak N}_1$ and is squarefree.  For consistency and clarity, 
we will denote complete $L$-functions by $L^*(s, -)$ and incomplete $L$-functions just by $L(s, -)$.  However, we follow the usual convention that automorphic 
$L$-functions are normalized
so that $s=1/2$ is the central value, whereas $L$-functions for $f \in S_2({\mathfrak N})$
are normalized classically with $s=1$ the central value.

Let $K/F$ be a CM quadratic extension such that $K$ is unramified
at each ${\mathfrak p} | {\mathfrak N}$.  This means $K$ embeds in $B$ and, since we
are now assuming ${\mathcal O}$ is maximal, we may fix an embedding of $K$ into $B$
such that ${\mathfrak o}_K \subset {\mathcal O}$. Hence, for 
$t \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K) = K^\times {\backslash} \hat K^\times / \hat {\mathfrak o}_K^\times$, we can associate the
quaternionic ideal class $x(t) \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ via $x(t) = B^\times t \hat {\mathcal O}^\times$.
Fix a character $\chi$ of ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K)$.  Put the product of local Tamagawa measures
on ${\mathbb A}_F^\times$ and ${\mathbb A}_K^\times$, and the counting measure on $K^\times$.
For $\phi \in {\mathcal M}$, define the period

Let $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$ be an eigenform.  
Then $\phi$ generates an irreducible cuspidal automorphic representation $\pi$ of 
$B^\times({\mathbb A}_F)$ with trivial central character.  The period
$P_\chi$ extends to a linear functional on $\pi$ via the same defining integral.  
Suppose $P_\chi(\phi) \ne 0$ so $P_\chi \not \equiv 0$. 
Then for each place $v$ of $F$, $\pi_v$ has a nonzero local $K_v^\times$-invariant linear
functional $\ell_v$.  It is well known that the functional $\ell_v$ is unique up to scaling,
and we normalize the $\ell_v$'s so that $P_\chi = \prod \ell_v$ (i.e., this 
factorization holds factorizable forms in $\pi$).

For each finite place $v$, Gross and Prasad
\cite{gross-prasad} defined a test vector $\phi_v \in \pi_v$ such that $\ell_v(\phi_v) \ne 0$.
In our setting, the Gross--Prasad test vector $\phi_v$ is the (unique up to scaling)
vector in $\pi_v$ fixed by ${\mathcal O}_v^\times$.  (This is not true if ${\mathcal O}$ is not maximal.)
This implies that $\phi = \prod \phi_v$ as a function on $B^\times({\mathbb A}_F)$ where
$\phi_v$ is a suitably normalized (to guarantee convergence) Gross--Prasad test
vector for $v < \infty$ and $\phi_v = 1$ for $v | \infty$.

In particular, if ${\mathfrak p} \nmid h_K^2$, then $L(1, f_K) \ne 0$.
\end{thm}

We remark that we could also allow $K$ to be ramified at ${\mathfrak p} | {\mathfrak N}_1$, but
then one needs to exclude the $L$-factors at such ${\mathfrak p}$ (cf.\ \cite{mw}).

\begin{proof}
Using the inverse Jacquet--Langlands lift, $f$ corresponds to a $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$
that can be normalized as above to have integral values in ${\mathbb Q}(f)$ such that 
$\phi \equiv \phi_0  \equiv 1 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$.  Then $P^0_\chi(\phi) \equiv P^0_\chi(\phi_0) {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} {\mathfrak p}$, and $P^0_\chi(\phi_0)$ is either $h_K$ or $0$ according to whether $\chi$ is 
trivial or not.
\end{proof}

\begin{rem}
It may be more natural to normalize
$\phi$ to be an integral form $\phi_1$ such that the gcd of all its values is 1.  Defining
the algebraic $L$-value in the same way in terms of $\phi_1$ will still give an algebraic integer, and we have $\phi = c \phi_1$ for some algebraic integer $c$ prime to ${\mathfrak p}$, 
so this normalization would result in a factor $c^2$ in the above congruence.  Unfortunately,
we do not know how to compute $c$ in general.
\end{rem}

Finally, we briefly illustrate how one can use $L$-values to recover 
information about the map ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$, and use this to give
an example where $L(1/2, f_K)^{\rm alg} \not \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} p$ and $L(1/2, f, \chi) \ne 0$
but $L(1/2, f, \chi) \equiv 0 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} p$ for a nontrivial ideal class character $\chi$ of $K$.

\begin{ex} Suppose $F={\mathbb Q}$, $N=11$ and $p=5$.  Then 
the quaternion algebra $B$ ramified
at $11$ and $\infty$ has class number $2$.    Write ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O}) = \{ x_1, x_2 \}$.  Then, up to reordering, $w_1 = 3$ and
$w_2 = 2$.  Here $\dim {\mathcal S} = 1$, and we can define $\phi \in {\mathcal S}$
by  $\phi(x_1) = 6$ and $\phi(x_2) = -4$.  This is normalized as we specified above,
and $[\phi, \phi] = 20$.
(With our alternative normalization, we could take
$\phi_1(x_1) = 3$ and $\phi_1(x_2) = -2$, so $[\phi_1, \phi_1] = 5$.)  

Let $K={\mathbb Q}(\sqrt{-23})$, which has class number 3,
and ${\mathcal O}$ be a maximal order of $B$ containing 
${\mathfrak o}_K$.
Our theorem says that 
$L^{\rm alg}(1, f_K) \equiv h_K^2 \equiv 4 {\, \, \mathrm{mod} \, \,} 5$, where $f \in S_2(11)$ is the unique
normalized cusp form.  Indeed, one can compute $L(1/2, f_K)^{\rm alg} = 4$.
On the other hand, the normalized period for $\chi=1$ is 
$P^0_1(\phi) = \sum_{t \in {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K)} \phi(x(t)) = 10a - 12$, 
where $0 \le a \le 3$ is the number of classes of ${\mathfrak o}_K$ mapping to $x_1$.
Since $|P^0_1(\phi)|^2 = 4$, we deduce $a=1$.   
Hence $x(t_1) = x_1$ and $x(t_2) = x(t_3) = x_2$ for some ordering $t_1, t_2, t_3$
of the ideal classes of ${\mathfrak o}_K$, i.e., the map ${\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathfrak o}_K) \to {\mathrm{Cl}}({\mathcal O})$ is surjective
with fibers of size $1$ and $2$ over $x_1$ and $x_2$, respectively.

Now let $\chi$ be one of the nontrivial idele class characters.  Then the
$\zeta_i :=\chi(t_i)$'s are the distinct 3rd roots of unity in some order, and 
$P^0_\chi(\phi) = 6 \zeta_1 -4 \zeta_2 - 4 \zeta_3 = 10 \zeta_1$.  Hence we see
$L^{\rm alg}(1, f, \chi)$ is nonzero, but $0 \text{ \rm{mod} } 5$.
\end{ex}

We remark that with $f$ as in the previous example, 
one can use the values of $\phi$ to conclude
$L^{\rm alg}(1, f_K) \in \{ 4(5a-2h_K)^2 : 0 \le a \le h_K \}$ for any imaginary quadratic $K$ 
unramified  at 11.
